outcomes.OBJ-1: Decide whether a scenario is IoT and explain why/why not.
outcomes.OBJ-2: Choose appropriate connectivity (internet vs private networks; Wi-Fi, cellular, RFID).
outcomes.OBJ-3: Match overlapping tech to its role (5G, big data/AI, digital twins, cybersecurity).
outcomes.OBJ-4: Spot common IoT security pitfalls and choose effective mitigations.
outcomes.OBJ-5: Sequence the IoT data loop: Sense → Share → Process → Act.

IOT-1.stimulus: Bluetooth headphones stream music from a phone. Is this IoT by the definition used here?
answer_rules: IoT applications sense an environment, then share, process, and act on that info.

any_connected_is_iot.contrast: IoT involves sensing something about the world and acting on it.
any_connected_is_iot.next_try: Check whether environment sensing or actuation is present.

hints: Does this device sense the environment or act on it automatically?
Our definition needs: sense → share → process → act.
Headphones play audio but don't sense/act on the environment.
IOT-1.exemplar: No. Headphones don't sense the environment or act on sensed data.

IOT-2.stimulus: A warehouse uses RFID tags on pallets. Gates read the tags and update the inventory system. Is this IoT?
answer_rules: The system senses (RFID), shares data, processes it, then triggers actions like stock updates.

rfid_not_iot.why: RFID can be part of IoT when it senses and shares object state.
rfid_not_iot.contrast: RFID readers sense tags and update systems in real time.
rfid_not_iot.next_try: Re-evaluate with the 'sense → share → process → act' loop.

hints: What is being sensed here?
RFID readers collect tag IDs at the gate.
The data updates inventory—this is the act step.
IOT-2.exemplar: Yes. RFID readers sense tag data and trigger inventory actions.

IOT-3.stimulus: A smart thermostat uses motion sensors and a schedule to heat your house automatically. IoT?
answer_rules: Sensors detect occupancy; data is processed; heating is adjusted (act).

needs_internet.why: The 'internet' isn't required—only a device network that senses and acts.
needs_internet.contrast: IoT can run on local/private networks.
needs_internet.next_try: Focus on the loop, not the public internet.

hints: Does it sense the environment?
What is the action taken based on sensed data?
Heating adjusts based on motion/time: classic IoT.
IOT-3.exemplar: Yes—senses motion and time, then acts by changing heat.

IOT-4.stimulus: A laptop browses the web. Is that IoT?
answer_rules: General-purpose computers are not IoT by themselves.

internet_equals_iot.contrast: We need sensing/actuation of the physical world.

hints: Is anything physical being sensed?
Browsing alone doesn't sense the environment.
So this is not IoT.

NET-1.stimulus: A factory's sensors report to a local server on the shop floor only. Pick the best connectivity.
options: RFID-only readers (no active radio on sensors)
answer_rules: IoT doesn't require the public internet.

must_use_internet.why: The public internet isn't required for IoT to work.
must_use_internet.contrast: Local networks can fully support IoT apps.
must_use_internet.next_try: Choose a non-internet option when scope is on-prem only.

hints: Where does the data need to go?
Only to a local server.
Then a private/local network fits best.
NET-1.exemplar: Private/local network—keeps data on site; internet not required.

NET-2.stimulus: A delivery firm tracks boxes at gates with short-range readers. Best connectivity?
options: RFID-only readers (no active radio on sensors)
NET-2.answer_correct: RFID-only readers (no active radio on sensors)

rfid_misunderstood.why: The scenario uses passive RFID tags.
rfid_misunderstood.contrast: Readers sense tags; items don't need Wi-Fi/cellular radios.

hints: What tech scans tags at gates?
Think RFID.
Choose RFID readers.
NET-2.exemplar: RFID readers—gates scan passive tags; no Wi-Fi on boxes.

NET-3.stimulus: A car uploads maintenance data to the manufacturer from anywhere. Best connectivity?
options: RFID-only readers (no active radio on sensors)
answer_rules: Wide-area connectivity is needed on the road.

wifi_everywhere.why: Wi-Fi lacks coverage away from hotspots.
wifi_everywhere.contrast: Cellular is designed for mobility & coverage.

hints: Does it need coverage while moving?
Wi-Fi is limited to hotspots.
Use cellular + internet.

MATCH-1.stimulus: Match each technology to the role it plays in IoT.
pairs_right: Analyze large sensor streams to find patterns
Live virtual copy of a physical system

answer_correct.Big data / AI: Analyze large sensor streams to find patterns
answer_correct.Digital twin: Live virtual copy of a physical system

twin_as_3d_only.why: A digital twin isn't just 3D or network tech; it's a live data-fed model.
twin_as_3d_only.contrast: Sensors feed the twin to mirror the real object.
twin_as_3d_only.next_try: Match digital twin to 'live virtual copy'.

hints: Which tech talks; which tech thinks; which tech mirrors; which tech protects?
5G talks; AI thinks; twin mirrors; security protects.
Map accordingly.

TRIAGE-1.stimulus: Sort each card into Vulnerability or Mitigation.
cards: Using the factory-set default password on an outdoor security camera.
IoT device that cannot be updated over the network (you must visit it in person to install updates).
Putting IoT devices on their own separate network so they cannot directly reach more sensitive systems.
Using strong, unique passwords for each IoT device and login.
IoT device installed where anyone can easily reach it and open its case.
Regularly installing software updates on all IoT devices.

vulnerability: Using the factory-set default password on an outdoor security camera.
IoT device that cannot be updated over the network (you must visit it in person to install updates).
IoT device installed where anyone can easily reach it and open its case.
mitigation: Putting IoT devices on their own separate network so they cannot directly reach more sensitive systems.
Using strong, unique passwords for each IoT device and login.
Regularly installing software updates on all IoT devices.

Using the factory-set default password o.why: Default passwords are widely known and easy for attackers to guess, making the device vulnerable to unauthorized access.

IoT device that cannot be updated over t.why: Devices that can't be updated remotely stay vulnerable to known security flaws because updates are difficult and often neglected.

Putting IoT devices on their own separat.why: Network segmentation limits damage if an IoT device is compromised—it's a defensive strategy that makes the system safer.

Using strong, unique passwords for each.why: Strong, unique passwords prevent unauthorized access and make it harder for attackers to break into devices.

IoT device installed where anyone can ea.why: Physical access allows tampering, theft, or direct attacks on the device's internal components.

Regularly installing software updates on.why: Software updates patch security vulnerabilities and protect devices from known attack methods.

segmentation_confused.why: Separating IoT devices on their own network limits damage if a device is compromised.
segmentation_confused.contrast: It's a defensive control that contains problems, not a risk by itself.
segmentation_confused.next_try: Place this network separation strategy under Mitigation.

hints: Ask: does this make the system weaker (vulnerability) or safer (mitigation)?
Strong passwords and regular updates make systems safer.
Default passwords, no remote updates, and easy physical access make systems weaker.
TRIAGE-1.exemplar: Vulnerabilities: factory-set passwords, devices that can't be updated remotely, devices anyone can reach and open. Mitigations: separate network for IoT devices, strong unique passwords, regular software updates.

TRIAGE-2.stimulus: Sort each card into Vulnerability or Mitigation.
cards: Unencrypted data transmission between IoT devices and the cloud.
Two-factor authentication for accessing IoT device controls.
IoT device using an outdated operating system with known security flaws.
Regular security audits and penetration testing of IoT systems.

vulnerability: Unencrypted data transmission between IoT devices and the cloud.
IoT device using an outdated operating system with known security flaws.
mitigation: Two-factor authentication for accessing IoT device controls.
Regular security audits and penetration testing of IoT systems.

Unencrypted data transmission between Io.why: Unencrypted data can be intercepted and read by attackers, exposing sensitive information.

Two-factor authentication for accessing.why: Two-factor authentication adds an extra security layer, making unauthorized access much harder.

IoT device using an outdated operating s.why: Outdated systems have known vulnerabilities that attackers can easily exploit.

Regular security audits and penetration.why: Regular audits help identify and fix security weaknesses before attackers can exploit them.

encryption_confused.why: Unencrypted data transmission is a vulnerability because it exposes data to interception.
encryption_confused.contrast: Encryption protects data in transit, making it a mitigation strategy.

hints: Ask: does this make the system weaker (vulnerability) or safer (mitigation)?
Two-factor auth and audits make systems safer.
Unencrypted data and outdated systems make systems weaker.
TRIAGE-2.exemplar: Vulnerabilities: unencrypted data, outdated OS. Mitigations: two-factor auth, security audits.

SEQ-1.stimulus: Order the IoT loop from first to last.

act_first.why: Action comes after data is sensed and analyzed.
act_first.contrast: Correct order is Sense → Share → Process → Act.

hints: What must happen before action?
We need data and analysis first.
Sense then share then process then act.
